caption.title: Grading of use wear by zone (adapted from Haslam et al., 2013)

tr.td: Distinct indentations from discrete strikes that can culminate in the creation of more general craters in the stone surface
Rounding and flattening of the tool surface, especially the protruding parts on the points and edges.
A breakage of the tool caused by chipping or flaking
Trace - minimal and isolated damage. Isolated points of impact
Overlapping impact points that have formed a coherent platform of damage
Surface clearly damaged but limited evidence of repeated use.
Moderate - larger fractureaffecting < 30% of the use zone
Cumulative damage with a pitting to a depth of 2 mm
Cumulative - rounding can be observed and felt.
Extensive - Fracture affecting between 30% and 60% of the use zone
Cratered - a larger more extensive indentation that is more than 2 mm deep and 5 mm in diameter.
More progressive rounding that has produced a flatter surface on the use zone.
General - fracture extending beyond 60% of the use zone
